pull.title: WIP contrib: Add keys.openpgp.org as backup server
pull.body:
Due to DOS attacks, most keyservers are read-only or have strict upload limits. I can no longer upload my key to SKS keyservers. See also https://gist.github.com/rjhansen/67ab921ffb4084c865b3618d6955275f#executive-summary

The keyservers only have an outdated key of mine, so all gpg --verify checks will fail. For example, in the travis sanity check: https://travis-ci.org/github/bitcoin/bitcoin/builds/664176384

Fix this by switching to keys.openpgp.org as backup.

verification.payload:
tree ec708ffed52385546a2e723c01f9e9770210b52b
parent 5c9d408b2dd8c7a5b40b3e6051bb095eaad62604
author MarcoFalke <falke.marco@gmail.com> 1584633349 -0400
committer MarcoFalke <falke.marco@gmail.com> 1584633064 -0400

contrib: Add keys.openpgp.org as backup server

events.message: contrib: Add keys.openpgp.org as backup server

events.body: Concept ACK on adding it as a backup server but I would leave Ubuntu as number 1 like it already is otherwise the PR title is wrong

If someone has an alternative that is:

* running stable
* where I (and every other Bitcoin Core contributor) can upload their key

Please let me know

Could someone please run this locally. I fail to see which key is expired:

```sh
$ gpg --fingerprint --fingerprint   marco
pub   rsa4096 2015-12-14 [SC]
      B8B3 F1C0 E58C 15DB 6A81  D30C 3648 A882 F431 6B9B
...
sub   rsa2048 2015-12-14 [S] [expires: 2020-09-09]
      FE09 B823 E6D8 3A3B C798  3EAA 2D7F 2372 E50F E137
...



$ git log --show-signature b860915f8b0dae98e57a254d11575ea41f5c5a79 
commit b860915f8b0dae98e57a254d11575ea41f5c5a79
gpg: Signature made Fri 10 Feb 2017 12:02:56 PM EST
gpg:                using RSA key 2D7F2372E50FE137
gpg: Good signature from "Marco Falke <marco.falke@tum.de>" [unknown]
gpg:                 aka "Marco Falke <falke.marco@gmail.com>" [unknown]
gpg: Note: This key has expired!
Primary key fingerprint: B8B3 F1C0 E58C 15DB 6A81  D30C 3648 A882 F431 6B9B
     Subkey fingerprint: FE09 B823 E6D8 3A3B C798  3EAA 2D7F 2372 E50F E137
Merge: 2447c1024e 9db8eecac1
```


<!--

This is the merge function of the ubuntu keyserver: https://github.com/hockeypuck/hockeypuck/blame/d43a9d714d03a1ac9c542efb05d7251f5d7f8542/src/hockeypuck/openpgp/resolve.go#L108

For some reason I had to create a new subkey to get my key to merge and yield a different hash, thus get updated. Huh :man_shrugging: 

I guess this is solved.

```
$ gpg --fingerprint --fingerprint   marco
pub   rsa4096/0x3648A882F4316B9B 2015-12-14 [SC]
      Key fingerprint = B8B3 F1C0 E58C 15DB 6A81  D30C 3648 A882 F431 6B9B
uid                   [  full  ] Marco Falke <marco.falke@tum.de>
uid                   [  full  ] Marco Falke <falke.marco@gmail.com>

git log --show-signature b860915f8b0dae98e57a254d11575ea41f5c5a79 
commit b860915f8b0dae98e57a254d11575ea41f5c5a79
gpg: Signature made Fri 10 Feb 2017 06:02:56 PM CET
gpg:                using RSA key 2D7F2372E50FE137
gpg: Good signature from "Marco Falke <marco.falke@tum.de>" [full]
gpg:                 aka "Marco Falke <falke.marco@gmail.com>" [full]
gpg: Note: This key has expired!
Primary key fingerprint: B8B3 F1C0 E58C 15DB 6A81  D30C 3648 A882 F431 6B9B
     Subkey fingerprint: FE09 B823 E6D8 3A3B C798  3EAA 2D7F 2372 E50F E137
```
Oh, does it not show the subkey `FE09 B823 E6D8 3A3B C798  3EAA 2D7F 2372 E50F E137`? I think I used that key to sign commits back then.

I got into a fight with gpg yesterday and was unable to list keys, had to rebuild my public keyring. Anyhow it shows the following keys:
```
pub   rsa4096/0x3648A882F4316B9B 2015-12-14 [SC]
      Key fingerprint = B8B3 F1C0 E58C 15DB 6A81  D30C 3648 A882 F431 6B9B
uid                   [ unknown] Marco Falke <marco.falke@tum.de>
uid                   [ unknown] Marco Falke <falke.marco@gmail.com>
sub   rsa2048/0x6DF9EDF1F6B61B9A 2015-12-14 [E] [expires: 2020-09-09]
      Key fingerprint = B6C7 2B4A 758C C29B 483E  82C7 6DF9 EDF1 F6B6 1B9A
sub   rsa2048/0x2D7F2372E50FE137 2015-12-14 [S] [expires: 2020-09-09]
      Key fingerprint = FE09 B823 E6D8 3A3B C798  3EAA 2D7F 2372 E50F E137
sub   rsa4096/0xD2EA4850E7528B25 2017-03-01 [S] [expires: 2020-09-09]
      Key fingerprint = 60B0 B8A4 02FB 386B 24A0  39AC D2EA 4850 E752 8B25
sub   rsa3072/0xCE2B75697E69A548 2018-01-23 [S] [expires: 2020-09-09]
      Key fingerprint = FAB5 4FA1 46A1 AC8F 6C2C  6613 CE2B 7569 7E69 A548
```
~~So yes â€” it's lacking that subkey.~~
Eh no, it isn't, sorry, it's the second one.
```
      Key fingerprint = FE09 B823 E6D8 3A3B C798  3EAA 2D7F 2372 E50F E137
```

Anyhow we should probably merge this as it gets travis to pass again.
(though travis is down at the moment)
ACK fa3a0fcd094b934377ad88242d1a4d1e6c03d6f4

>  Eh no, it isn't, sorry, it's the second one.

Right, and it is not expired. That problem seems to be a problem completely unrelated to keyservers.

rename.from: contrib: Add keys.openpgp.org as backup server
rename.to: WIP contrib: Add keys.openpgp.org as backup server

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -21,6 +21,7 @@ test/lint/lint-all.sh
 
 if [ "$TRAVIS_REPO_SLUG" = "bitcoin/bitcoin" ] && [ "$TRAVIS_EVENT_TYPE" = "cron" ]; then
     git log --merges --before="2 days ago" -1 --format='%H' > ./contrib/verify-commits/trusted-sha512-root-commit
-    travis_retry gpg --keyserver hkp://keyserver.ubuntu.com:80 --recv-keys $(<contrib/verify-commits/trusted-keys) &&
+    ${CI_RETRY_EXE} gpg --keyserver hkps://keys.openpgp.org    --recv-keys $(<contrib/verify-commits/trusted-keys) &&
+    ${CI_RETRY_EXE} gpg --keyserver hkp://keyserver.ubuntu.com --recv-keys $(<contrib/verify-commits/trusted-keys) &&
comments.body: Why not put the key servers into an array and loop through it until it finds keys. Maybe it's a bit too much for this PR but if we add more backup servers from time to time it'll get useful

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -21,6 +21,7 @@ test/lint/lint-all.sh
 
 if [ "$TRAVIS_REPO_SLUG" = "bitcoin/bitcoin" ] && [ "$TRAVIS_EVENT_TYPE" = "cron" ]; then
     git log --merges --before="2 days ago" -1 --format='%H' > ./contrib/verify-commits/trusted-sha512-root-commit
-    travis_retry gpg --keyserver hkp://keyserver.ubuntu.com:80 --recv-keys $(<contrib/verify-commits/trusted-keys) &&
+    ${CI_RETRY_EXE} gpg --keyserver hkps://keys.openpgp.org    --recv-keys $(<contrib/verify-commits/trusted-keys) &&
comments.body: You aren't adding it as a backup server, you make ubuntu a backup server
